hero.title: FxLocus Academy: From fundamentals to execution
hero.subtitle: FxLocus Academy organizes FX knowledge into four modules: Fundamentals, Technical Analysis, Trading Strategies, and Risk Management. Each topic expands into practical points and exercises so you can turn concepts into repeatable actions.
highlights: A complete learning path across basics, tools, strategies, and risk.
Each topic opens with detailed teaching points.
Exercises turn understanding into reviewable actions.
hero.risk: For education and training only. Not investment advice.

title: Learning Path Overview
lead: Start by learning the trading language and market structure, then train indicators and strategies, and finally lock execution in with risk management.

sections.title: Fundamentals
sections.subtitle: Build the trading language and understand the market structure first.

items.title: FX Trading Basics
items.summary: Understand currency pairs and the core mechanics of FX trading.
points: What is Forex: the global market for currency exchange.
FX trading is buying or selling a currency pair to profit from exchange rate changes.
Major pairs, crosses, and commodity currencies - differences and examples.
Market traits: high liquidity, 24-hour trading, and decentralized execution.
items.practice: Exercise: list 10 major pairs and mark base vs quote currency.

items.title: FX Market Structure
items.summary: Know the market participants and session rhythm.
points: Global structure: interbank market at the core, retail at the edge.
Trading sessions: Asia, Europe, US, and overlapping periods.
Volatility by session: Asia ranges, London expands, US adds data spikes.
Market maker vs ECN/STP: pricing, slippage, and execution differences.
items.practice: Exercise: compare average session volatility for one pair.

items.title: Spreads and Commissions
items.summary: Know your true transaction cost before trading.
points: Fixed vs floating spreads: stability vs variable liquidity cost.
Commission calculation: per lot or per side, include round-trip fees.
Hidden costs: slippage, swaps/rollover, and execution delay.
True cost = spread + commission + expected slippage.
items.practice: Exercise: calculate round-trip cost for 1 lot EURUSD on your broker.

items.title: Leverage and Margin
items.summary: Leverage magnifies exposure and risk - understand the rules.
points: Leverage uses margin to control a larger notional position.
Initial vs maintenance margin define when you can open and keep a trade.
Margin calls and liquidation protect the broker when equity drops.
Common mistakes: using max leverage or ignoring volatility.
items.practice: Exercise: compute margin required for the same size with different leverage.

items.title: Macro Data Impact
items.summary: Data moves markets when it surprises expectations.
points: Key releases: NFP, CPI, rate decisions, GDP.
Pre/post release behavior: positioning, spread widening, whipsaws.
Expectation vs actual: surprises matter more than absolute numbers.
Trade/avoid strategies: wait for confirmation or plan the event.
items.practice: Exercise: review one NFP release and log the 15-minute volatility.

items.title: Currency Pair Logic
items.summary: Strength, rate differentials, and correlations drive direction.
points: Currency pairs express relative strength, not absolute value.
Rate differentials drive medium-term flows (carry).
Safe-haven vs risk currencies behave differently in stress.
Correlation analysis: positive/negative links like EURUSD vs DXY.
items.practice: Exercise: compare two correlated pairs and mark co-movement.

items.title: Market Participants
items.summary: Know who moves the market and why.
points: Central banks: rates, guidance, and intervention.
Commercial banks: liquidity, hedging, client flows.
Funds and institutions: trend-driving capital flows.
Retail traders: smaller size, higher emotion bias.
items.practice: Exercise: list objectives for three participant types in a crisis.

sections.title: Technical Analysis
sections.subtitle: Turn chart tools into trainable pattern recognition.

items.title: Bollinger Bands
items.summary: Use volatility bands to read contraction and expansion.
points: Bands are built from a moving average and standard deviations.
Contraction signals low volatility, expansion signals release.
Use pullbacks in trends, ranges in sideways markets.
Common mistake: touching the band without context.
items.practice: Exercise: mark 3 squeezes that expanded into trends.

items.title: Candlestick Patterns
items.summary: Candles show intent - context makes them valid.
points: Single candles: hammer, engulfing, doji - key meanings.
Multi-candle patterns: morning/evening star, inside/outside bars.
Candles reflect sentiment shifts, not standalone signals.
High-probability setups need location, trend, and confirmation.
items.practice: Exercise: label 5 valid engulfing patterns and explain context.

items.title: MACD in Practice
items.summary: Track momentum changes and trend strength.
points: DIF, DEA, and histogram describe momentum and trend shifts.
Crossovers are meaningful only with trend context.
Divergence signals weakening momentum, wait for confirmation.
Use MACD as a filter, not a standalone trigger.
items.practice: Exercise: find one top and one bottom divergence, judge validity.

items.title: EMA System
items.summary: Use EMAs to frame trend structure and pullback entries.
points: EMA reacts faster than SMA, better for trend changes.
Multi-timeframe EMA sets help align direction and entries.
Divergence = stronger trend; convergence = range.
EMAs often act as dynamic support/resistance.
items.practice: Exercise: mark EMA pullback entries in a trend.

items.title: RSI Guide
items.summary: Measure momentum and range behavior.
points: Overbought/oversold is not an automatic reversal signal.
RSI divergence highlights fading momentum.
RSI works best in ranges; raise thresholds in trends.
Common settings: 14 default, adjust by timeframe.
items.practice: Exercise: map RSI highs/lows inside a range.

items.title: Price Pattern Identification
items.summary: Identify reversal, continuation, and false break structures.
points: Reversals: head-and-shoulders, double tops/bottoms.
Continuation: flags, triangles, wedges.
False breaks: traps and quick rejections.
Multi-timeframe confluence increases reliability.
items.practice: Exercise: label a triangle breakout and the retest.

items.title: Support, Resistance, Trendlines
items.summary: Key levels show consensus and liquidity.
points: Support/resistance reflects order clusters and consensus.
Combine static levels with dynamic levels for accuracy.
Trendlines need at least two clear touches.
Role reversal is a core signal of trend continuation.
items.practice: Exercise: draw three key levels on one chart.

items.title: Price Action Strategies
items.summary: Trade structure and signals without heavy indicators.
points: Naked charts focus on structure, location, and pace.
Key level + signal confirmation builds high-quality setups.
Fake breakouts trap liquidity near range edges.
Pin Bar / Inside Bar setups require trend and location.
items.practice: Exercise: find a Pin Bar at a key level and define the stop.

sections.title: Trading Strategies
sections.subtitle: Combine tools into executable strategy frameworks.

items.title: Day Trading Guide
items.summary: Capture intraday moves with fast execution.
points: Short holding period, avoid overnight risk.
Common timeframes: M5/M15/H1.
Intraday high/low strategies: opening range, session extremes.
Best for traders who can monitor the market and stay disciplined.
items.practice: Exercise: track one week of intraday high/low breakouts.

items.title: Swing Trading
items.summary: Trade the main leg of a trend with fewer decisions.
points: Swing logic: capture trend continuation after pullbacks.
Pullback entries reduce noise when aligned with structure.
Multi-timeframe analysis: higher timeframe for bias, lower for entry.
Position management: partial exits and trailing stops.
items.practice: Exercise: find an H4 trend with an H1 pullback entry.

items.title: Scalping Skills
items.summary: Ultra-short-term trading relies on execution quality.
points: Scalping targets small moves with high frequency.
Requires tight spreads and fast execution.
Risks: slippage, fatigue, and cost accumulation.
Not ideal for beginners without strict routines.
items.practice: Exercise: simulate 10 scalps and log slippage.

items.title: Trend Following System
items.summary: Let trends run and manage positions with structure.
points: Trend definition: higher highs/lows or aligned moving averages.
Confirmation via structure + MAs + momentum.
Pyramiding and reductions must keep risk controlled.
Trend end signals: structure breaks and momentum loss.
items.practice: Exercise: design add/reduce rules for one trend trade.

items.title: Breakout Strategies
items.summary: Trade direction once a range resolves.
points: Identify ranges by compression and repeated tests.
True vs false breakouts require retest confirmation.
Volume and volatility help validate the break.
Handle failed breaks with fast stops or reversals.
items.practice: Exercise: write entry and failure rules for a breakout.

sections.title: Risk Management
sections.subtitle: Turn risk control into rules for long-term survival.

items.title: Risk Management Basics
items.summary: Risk control keeps you in the game.
points: Risk management outweighs strategy in long-term survival.
Survival logic: control drawdowns and stay consistent.
Trading is about expectancy, not just win rate.
Keep losses small to preserve compounding.
items.practice: Exercise: calculate expectancy and drawdown for your system.

items.title: Position Sizing & Capital
items.summary: Consistent risk per trade stabilizes the equity curve.
points: Fixed fractional risk is the most common method.
1% / 2% per trade keeps losing streaks survivable.
Plan for drawdowns with risk reduction rules.
Stable equity curves come from consistent risk.
items.practice: Exercise: define a risk-reduction rule after a losing streak.

items.title: Stop-Loss Methods
items.summary: Stops define boundaries, not failures.
points: Fixed stops: pre-set by pips or cash risk.
Technical stops: based on structure or volatility.
Time stops: exit if price stagnates.
Trailing stops: protect profit while letting trends run.
items.practice: Exercise: write three stop methods for the same setup.

items.title: Trading Psychology
items.summary: Emotional control is the core of execution.
points: Greed and fear distort decisions and timing.
Overtrading creates fatigue and higher costs.
Revenge trading magnifies losses without edge.
Discipline comes from plans, journaling, and review.
items.practice: Exercise: list three emotional triggers and alternative actions.

items.title: Risk-Reward Optimization
items.summary: Improve expectancy by shaping R:R.
points: R:R often matters more than win rate.
Lower win rates can still be profitable with strong R:R.
Improve expectancy via entries, exits, and stops.
Compounding mindset: manage results over cycles.
items.practice: Exercise: simulate 10 trades under different R:R ratios.

cta.title: Want a more structured learning path?
cta.lead: You can start anywhere, but we recommend solidifying fundamentals first, then moving to technical and strategy modules, and finally stabilizing execution with risk control.
cta.note: All content is for education and training only.
